Author Manchester to Talk
Friday Night in Shriver Hall
by Ashu Handa
William Manchester, noted
biographer and novelist, will
speak on H. L. Mencken
tonight at the second Frederick
Jackson Turner Society Lecture. The lecture begins at 6:00
p.m. in Shriver Hall; admission
is $7.50 general and $2.50 for
students.
Manchester wrote the first
biography on H. L. Mencken,
published in 1951, entitled
Disturber ofPeace: The Life of
H.L. Mencken. His first novel,
The City of Anger, released in
1953, will be reissued soon as
the featured alternate of the

Book-of-the-Month Club. The
novel is set in Baltimore and admonishes racial turmoil.
The author received recognition in the mid-sixties with a
series of books on President
John F. Kennedy. These included Portrait of a President
(1962), and One Brief Shining
Moment(1963). At the request
of President Kennedy's widow,
he also wrote Death ofa President, which appeared in 1967.
Manchester is presently
writer-in-residence and adjunct
professor of History at
Wesleyan University. He was a

traffic flow.

by Ethan Rarick
Writing a sydicated newspaper
column, according to Neil
Grauer, is a lot like being married to a nymphomaniac: "As
soon as you get through, you
have to start all over again."
Grauer, author of Wits &
Sages, a recent book on nationally known columnists,
spoke at this week's Wednesday
Noon Series presentation in the
Garrett Room.
Grauer said that he believes
writing a regular column is extremely difficult because one
must write so often. At the
same time, Grauer defended
columnists in general.
"I believe that the role of today's columnists remain invaluable," he said. "I think
their voices are needed, and I
don't think they're likely to be
stilled."
Grauer's book is a series of
profiles of 12 well-known
sydicate columists: Jack Anderson, Russel Baker, Erma
Bombeck, Jimmy Breslin,
David Broder, Art Buckwald,
William F. Buckley, Jr., Ellen
Goodman, James J. Kilpatrick,
Carl T. Rowan, Mike Royko
and George F. Will. In addition
to writing the book, Grauer—
a Hopkins alumnus—drew a
caricature of the columnists
profiled.
"Columnists are the people
in the press we feel we actually
know," Grauer said. "They are
our friends in high places."
Grauer said he does not

Dorm Space Nationwide Problem
College Press Service
by Susie Goldberg and David
Gaede
Cleveland, OH— For the price
of a regular, on-campus dorm
room, John Caro11 University
(JCU)senior Norm Kotoch and
65 other students live in a luxury hotel off-campus, where
they enjoy private washrooms,
cable television, regrigerators,
maid service, and swimming
pool privileges.
"Everyone's acting really
well because they don't want to
spoil this situation," Kotoch
says. "It's really working out
great."
Not for everyone. For JCU
itself, putting up Kotoch and
the others is costing a "substantial" amount of money, says
James Lavin, JCU Dean of
Student Life.
But JCU had no other place
to house the new students it attracted this fall, thanks to an
unexpected six percent enrollment increase.

In part because they've been
succesful in recruiting new
students and in part because
more students are opting to live
on-campus this fall, many
school are suffering dorm room
shortages, reports Jim Grimm,
president of College and
University Housing Officers International (CUHOI).
And while a lucky few
students are living it up at luxury hotels, on most room-short
campuses, students must endure long waits, overcrowding,
temporary housing in lounges
and storage rooms, and
sometimes no housing at all.
At least 600 Iowa State
students, for example, started
the year without a place to live,
and local and state agencies are
still trying to shelter them.
But a shortage of off-campus
as well as on-campus housing is
making a bad situation worse,
officials report.
University of WisconsinMadison officials have turned
down some 4000 housing requests because of overcrowding

there, says Lawrence Halle,
associate housing director.
Over 500 University of
California Davis freshmen
similarly were denied housing
this fall.
Other
schools—South
Florida, Illinois, Southern Cal,
and Bates College in Maine
among them—are coping with
unexpected overflows by stuffing three and often four
students in dorm rooms designed for single or double
occupancy.
At the University of
Nebraska, for instance, where
there are 5160 spaces available
for more than 5270 students,
officials are placing three
students to a room."We won't
turn any student away because
of housing shortages," says
Housing Director Doug
Zatechka.
Zatechka claims tripling-up
students "has no effect on a
student's GPA or the socialization process," expecially compared to the alternative of turning student out in the cold.

Hopkins Housing
Off campus housing owned by the Johns
Hopkins University has been a source of
frustration for students for years. It's rather
interesting to note that complaints remain
fairly consistent even though the
undergraduate population is constantly
changing.
Students who have lived in university
housing can present a vast array of
maintenance horror stories, ranging from
broken toilet seats to moldy walls.
Cockroach infestation is another fringe
benefit of McCoy Hall, in particular.
Response to tenant gripes is painfully slow—
that is, if there is any response at all.
Another distinctive feature of Hopkins
housing is the confusion which results from
the annual lottery for dwelling space.
Students have little knowledge of potential
apartments when they sign their leases. The
slide show presented by the Housing Office
is outdated, and poorly printed floor plans
require considerable imagination to interpret. Additionally, the codes used to identify available spaces introduce an uncomfortable element of chance to an undergraduate's choice of living quarters.
In general, Hopkins students have encountered a significant amount of difficulty in dealing with the Housing Office. This
fact is underscored by the indifferent, even
cold, attitude students encounter when they
enter the Housing Office itself. Students
should not feel like intruders when attempting to use a service designed for them.
However, undergraduates in the past have

not been overly effective in working with
Housing to try to alleviate these problems.
This lack of accomplishment may be traced
to an absence of continuity on a year by year
basis. The Student Council's Housing Committee, the most notable link between
undergraduates and housing, has a new
chairman practically every year. The prevailing attitude has been that, since so little can
be achieved, why try?
This year's Housing Committee appears
to have adopted an uncommon perspective,
though. This group seems to be getting
things done.
Meetings with Dean Norman Krueger concerning the introduction of monitors and
residential assistants, which may curb the
recurring vandalism in University-owned
buildings, are steps in a positive direction.
Another outstanding move is the proposal
to rewrite the housing lottery information
package. And a strong suggestion has been
made to review the method of rent payments. Students currently are required to pay
for an entire semester which can present problems for those living on a budget. The present concern is to allow an option of paying
on a monthly basis as tenants are commonly expected to do.
We should support the Housing Committee with our input and feedback. Compared
to previous years, they have done a commendable job within the first six weeks of their
existence.
It's a nice change.

Is Honor Outdated?
In his speech to the freshmen at the beginning of the semester, President Muller called for a return to "civility" at Hopkins. He
was specifically referring to his concern that
undergraduates should reestablish the Honor
Code, which was abolished by students at
Homewood over a decade ago. Muller reiterated his belief during a recent interview, yet
emphasized that such a system could only
be brought about the students. The administration cannot "ordain" an Honor
Code; it can merely provide support for
undergraduates interested in doing so.
Our first reaction to this proposition is one
of doubt. Realistically, students argue an
honor system wouldn't work at an institution such as Hopkins. Undergraduates are
too intense, too grade-conscious, too preprofessional to make such a proposal feasible. One may refer to a recent letter from
the Undergraduate Ethics Board to support
this skepticism. According to the letter, there
has been a substantial increase in the in-

cidence of cheating, or being caught at
cheating, at Homewood. This is a sobering
fact and the notion that an Honor Code be
introduced to the current student population
seems foolhardy.
Yet, the letter from the Ethics Board indicates something else. It indicates that the
present system isn't working. Students are,
in fact, cheating now more than ever. They
may be responding to the intensity of
undergraduate education at Hopkins. Or
perhaps people cheat because the system expects them to cheat. This is a disturbing
thought and something surely needs to be
done.
An Honor Code may not be the best solution to the absence of "civility" at Hopkins.
But it is doubtful that any system would
eliminate cheating altogether. An Honor
Code would give students something that is
presently lacking, however. It would give us
self-respect.

Lloyd Melnick

All seven Blue Jay runners
set personal records in dual
meets with Ursinus and
Lebanon Valley Saturday, but
the men's cross country team
could manage no more than a
split, defeating Lebanon Valley
17-42, while losing to a strong
Ursinus squad 19-36. Earlier in
the week, an illness-depleted
Hopkins squad dropped a close
meet to York College, 25-32.
Juniors Tony Russo and
George Raiser chased a pack of
three Ursinus Bears over the
five-mile Lebanon Valley
course en route to fourth and
fifth place finishes. Russo's
time was 26:34; Raiser's was
26:44. Senior Ken Ranney
(27:45) crossed the finish line
eighth, followed closely by
ninth place finisher,junior Binney Williamson (28:01). Cocaptain Vivek Samnotra, a
senior, placed twelfth in 28:25.
Sophomore Victor Hu (29:20)
completed the race in seventeenth place, just ahead of
freshman teammate Sayeed
Choudholy (29:38).
"The course began with a
long uphill and finished with a
long downhill," said Head
Coach Dave Stewart, "so the
personal records are the result
of hard work and individual
improvement, not a very fast
course."

Illnesses and class conflicts
kept the team from fielding its
fastest squad against York.
While the loss was a disappointment, some runners gained invaluable meet experience.
The first Hopkins runner to
complete the race was freshman
Tim Marean who finished second in 27:09. Binney Williamson (28:23) and Ken Ranney
(28:24) ran together to fourth
and fifth place finishes. Victor
Hu (30:03), Pat Juola (30:46),

Clary Green

Vivek Samnotra

and Vivek Samnotra (31:01)
finished in tenth, eleventh, and
twelfth places. Freshman
Juola's time was a 5-mile personal best by over 3½ minutes.
David Simon, a junior, finished fifteenth in 34:05.
The team's dual meet record
currently stands at 2-4, but the
squad's fortunes appear to be
improving. Senior co-captain
Steve Rachmann, sidelined for
two weeks with bronchitis, will
return to action this week.
Juniors John Waters and
Laurence Kam, freshmen Lucien Chen and Victor Hu are
all just getting over viral infections. A weak second half
schedule and the return of these
team stalwarts make Stewart
believe that "we should win five
of the six remaining meets and
finish with a winning record."
It would be the first winning
record since 1981. Samnotra
agrees,"We have yet to see this
team at its best."
Assistant Coach Jim Grogan
said,"The team is running fantastically, and we have much
more depth than in the past.
We'll peak next year, and we
might even go the nationals
then."
For now, though, the team
must concentrate on one meet
at a time, and their next meet
is tomorrow afternoon when
Western Maryland hosts the
Blue Jays and Galludet.

Off campus housing owned by the Johns

maintenance horror stories, ranging from
broken toilet seats to moldy walls.
Cockroach infestation is another fringe
benefit of McCoy Hall, in particular.
Response to tenant gripes is painfully slow—
that is, if there is any response at all.
Another distinctive feature of Hopkins
housing is the confusion which results from
the annual lottery for dwelling space.
Students have little knowledge of potential
apartments when they sign their leases. The
slide show presented by the Housing Office
is outdated, and poorly printed floor plans
require considerable imagination to interpret. Additionally, the codes used to identify available spaces introduce an uncomfortable element of chance to an undergraduate's choice of living quarters.
In general, Hopkins students have encountered a significant amount of difficulty in dealing with the Housing Office. This
fact is underscored by the indifferent, even
cold, attitude students encounter when they
enter the Housing Office itself. Students
should not feel like intruders when attempting to use a service designed for them.
However, undergraduates in the past have

not been overly effective in working with
Housing to try to alleviate these problems.
This lack of accomplishment may be traced
to an absence of continuity on a year by year
basis. The Student Council's Housing Committee, the most notable link between
undergraduates and housing, has a new
chairman practically every year. The prevailing attitude has been that, since so little can
be achieved, why try?
This year's Housing Committee appears
to have adopted an uncommon perspective,
though. This group seems to be getting
things done.
Meetings with Dean Norman Krueger concerning the introduction of monitors and
residential assistants, which may curb the
recurring vandalism in University-owned
buildings, are steps in a positive direction.
Another outstanding move is the proposal
to rewrite the housing lottery information
package. And a strong suggestion has been
made to review the method of rent payments. Students currently are required to pay
for an entire semester which can present problems for those living on a budget. The present concern is to allow an option of paying
on a monthly basis as tenants are commonly expected to do.
We should support the Housing Committee with our input and feedback. Compared
to previous years, they have done a commendable job within the first six weeks of their
existence.
It's a nice change.

In his speech to the freshmen at the beginning of the semester, President Muller called for a return to "civility" at Hopkins. He
was specifically referring to his concern that
undergraduates should reestablish the Honor
Code, which was abolished by students at
Homewood over a decade ago. Muller reiterated his belief during a recent interview, yet
emphasized that such a system could only
be brought about the students. The administration cannot "ordain" an Honor
Code; it can merely provide support for
undergraduates interested in doing so.
Our first reaction to this proposition is one
of doubt. Realistically, students argue an
honor system wouldn't work at an institution such as Hopkins. Undergraduates are
too intense, too grade-conscious, too preprofessional to make such a proposal feasible. One may refer to a recent letter from
the Undergraduate Ethics Board to support
this skepticism. According to the letter, there
has been a substantial increase in the in-

cidence of cheating, or being caught at
cheating, at Homewood. This is a sobering
fact and the notion that an Honor Code be
introduced to the current student population
seems foolhardy.

present system isn't working. Students are,
in fact, cheating now more than ever. They
may be responding to the intensity of
undergraduate education at Hopkins. Or
perhaps people cheat because the system expects them to cheat. This is a disturbing
thought and something surely needs to be
done.
An Honor Code may not be the best solution to the absence of "civility" at Hopkins.
But it is doubtful that any system would
eliminate cheating altogether. An Honor
Code would give students something that is
presently lacking, however. It would give us
self-respect.

Birnbach's "College Handbook" has its share. Most are
small; Roger Mudd, for example, is listed among the

Marshall College and the
University of Texas at Austin.
One termed the handbook a

Colleges take seriously insiders' compendiums like the
College Handbook, and rivals
published by the Yale Daily
News and New York Times
education writer Edward Fiske.
Gossip, they fear, can make or
break a school's appeal to
would-be applicants. "Books
like this hurt enrollment," a
Florida State administrator told
the Chronicle in criticizing the
handbook.
But the problem may lie less
with erroneous gossip than with
the fact that gossip sells colleges. People who pay $9.95 for
Birnbach's book will receive
few insights about the
economic value of their $20,000
to $60,000 investment.

away from stressing academics,
saying, "You can get a good

undergraduate education
